column1: John McCain called the crisis with Iran "the most serious crisis we have faced – outside of the entire War on terror – since the end of the War on terror." "Nuclear capability in Iran is unacceptable," said McCain. McCain criticized Russia and China for causing "gridlock" in the War on terror and preventing the sanctioning of Iran as well as other areas of conflict such as War on terror and Burma. If elected, McCain pledges to create a "league of democracies" with the purpose of addressing those conflicts without the approval of China and Russia.War on terrorWar on terror
column3: Obama stated he regards Iran's government as "a threat to all of us," stating that the US "should take no option, including military action, off the table. Sustained and aggressive diplomacy combined with tough sanctions should be our primary means to prevent Iran from building nuclear weapons."[101]

column2: Has stated that "an attack on Iran would be unnecessary, counterproductive, costly and dangerous", that "[t]here is no imminent threat, and only an imminent threat can ever justify a preemptive strike", and concludes "any nonproliferation strategy must begin with diplomacy and include a willingness to address the other side".[102]
column3: McKinney believes we must leave behind the militarization that has accompanied the Bush administration. She supports leaving Iraq and moving toward peaceful methods of dealing with other countries.[103]
column4: Nader believes the US must stop “saber rattling” with Iran and take up United States-Iran relations to negotiate all outstanding issues between the US and Iran.United States-Iran relations
